info:
In Spanish, possessive adjectives and possessive pronouns also indicate ownership but have specific forms and usages.

Possessive Adjectives:

Function: Modify nouns to show possession.
Forms: mi(s), tu(s), su(s), nuestro/a(s), vuestro/a(s)
Usage: Placed before the noun, and they must agree in number (singular/plural) and sometimes gender (masculine/feminine) with the noun they modify.
Example Sentences:
Singular: "Este es mi libro." (This is my book.)
Plural: "Estos son mis libros." (These are my books.)
Gender Agreement: "Esta es nuestra casa." (This is our house. - feminine singular)
Possessive Pronouns:

Function: Replace nouns to show possession.
Forms: mío/a(s), tuyo/a(s), suyo/a(s), nuestro/a(s), vuestro/a(s)
Usage: Must agree in number and gender with the noun they replace. Often used with the definite article (el, la, los, las) before the pronoun.
Example Sentences:
Singular: "Este libro es mío." (This book is mine. - masculine singular)
Plural: "Estas casas son nuestras." (These houses are ours. - feminine plural)
In summary, in Spanish, possessive adjectives are placed before the noun and agree with it in number and sometimes gender. Possessive pronouns replace the noun and must also agree in number and gender with the noun they refer to.

native_answer: they are eating at their table

Singular: "Este libro es mío." (This book is mine. - masculine singular)
Plural: "Estas casas son nuestras." (These houses are ours. - feminine plural)
In summary, in Spanish, possessive adjectives are placed before the noun and agree with it in number and sometimes gender. Possessive pronouns replace the noun and must also agree in number and gender with the noun they refer to.
